Subject: Adult and Higher Education
Course Description: Planning, conducting and evaluating instruction for adults. Consideration is given to different beliefs and ways of thinking about teaching. [3-0-0]

Subject: Adult and Higher Education
Course Description: The history, roles, and activities of institutions in the field of adult education. Institutions in Canada, Great Britain, and the United States are emphasized, and some experiences in other countries are examined. [3-0-0]

Subject: Adult and Higher Education
Course Title: Developing Short Courses, Workshops and Seminars
Course Description: Organization and administration of adult education events such as short courses, seminars, workshops, conferences and institutes. [3-0-0]

Subject: Adult and Higher Education
Course Title: The Community Practice of Adult Education
Course Description: Community based adult education with particular emphasis on the application of knowledge of the social, economic, cultural and political environment in developing and conducting adult education programs with an for individuals and groups. [2-3-0]

Subject: Adult and Higher Education
Course Title: Diploma Seminar and Internship in Adult Education

Subject: Adult and Higher Education
Course Description: Survey of adult education theory and practice in Canada and the world. The focus is on the purpose and participation in, adult education, characteristics of learners, and the training of adult educators. [3-0-0; 3-0-0] Subscribe to ADHE_V Course Descriptions Introduction Courses by Subject Courses by Faculty/School/College UBC Academic Calendar Vancouver Campus 2016 1874 East Mall Vancouver,                  BC                  Canada V6T 1Z1 The University of British Columbia About UBC Contact UBC About the University News Events Careers Make a Gift Search UBC.ca UBC Campuses Vancouver Campus Okanagan Campus UBC Sites Robson Square Centre for Digital Media Faculty of Medicine Across BC Emergency Procedures | Terms of Use | UBC Copyright | Accessibility to top Calendar Sections Home Dates and Deadlines Academic Year Admissions Fees Establishment and Constitution Campus-wide Policies and Regulations Services, Facilities, and Organizations Research Units, Centres, and Institutes UBC Library Faculties, Colleges, and Schools Alternative Study Options Course Descriptions Emeriti Staff Enrolment Statistics 2023/24 Calendar History Calendar Archive Contact Us UBC Crest The official logo of the University of British Columbia. Subject: African Studies
Course Description: Cultural, historical, and geographical issues of African Studies.

Subject: African Studies
Course Description: An introduction to selected themes and historical approaches in African history. These may include African geography and identities, sources and methodology, pre-modern state formation, gender relations, world religions, labour systems, colonialism, and post-colonialism. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST 256 or HIST 256. Equivalency: HIST 256

Subject: African Studies
Course Description: Linguistic survey of the languages of Africa, including typological and historical connections between languages, individual and comparative surveys of sound systems, word structures, sentence structures, semantics, and sociolinguistic properties of a representative selection of languages. Equivalency: LING308

Subject: African Studies
Course Title: Arts of Africa and the African Diasporas
Course Description: Comparative exploration of art practices and their relationship to colonial and postcolonial histories. Equivalency: ARTH 309

Subject: African Studies
Course Description: Pre-colonial, colonial, and contemporary, emphasizing South Africa. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST 312 or HIST 312. Equivalency: HIST 312

Subject: African Studies
Course Description: The history of Africa in the 19th and 20th Centuries: the growth of Islam and Christianity, the impact of European colonialism, the development of nationalism, and the variety of different political and social outcomes after independence. Credit will be granted for only one of AFST 313 or HIST 313. Equivalency: HIST 313

Subject: African Studies
Course Description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the program website ( https://africanstudies.arts.ubc.ca ) for further details.

Subject: African Studies
Course Title: Perspectives in African Studies: Literary and Theoretical Approaches
Course Description: Major issues and theoretical approaches.

Subject: African Studies
Course Title: Perspectives in African Studies: A Social Science Approach
Course Description: Major issues and theoretical approaches.

Subject: African Studies
Course Title: Literatures and Cultures of Africa and/or the Middle East
Course Description: Literary and cultural works from Africa; some sections include Africa and the Middle East. Multiple perspectives on local, national, and global issues including colonialism, migration, transnationalism, education, art and politics. May include fiction, poetry, drama, digital media, and other forms. Consult department website for current year's offerings. Prerequisite: For ENGL courses at the 200- or 300- level, prior completion of at least one 100- level ENGL course is recommended. Equivalency: ENGL 370

Subject: African Studies
Course Title: Study of Sociolinguistics of a Selected African Language
Course Description: Selected African language with emphasis on major syntactic structures, vocabulary, conversation patterns, reading short texts, and the cultural and historical contexts of language use.

Subject: African Studies
Course Description: Key debates in the art of Africa and the African diaspora. Equivalency: ARTH 410 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: African Studies
Course Title: African Diasporic Culture in African Canadian Communities
Course Description: African diasporic culture in Canadian society, fostering dialogue with members of African Canadian communities on cultural values, traditions, memory, adaptation and change. Subject: American Sign Language
Course Title: American Sign Language and Deaf Culture I
Course Description: An introduction to understanding and producing American Sign Language. Emphasizes core grammar and vocabulary, contextual use, connection between language and Deaf culture. For students new to ASL.

Subject: American Sign Language
Course Title: American Sign Language and Deaf Culture II
Course Description: Skills in using ASL in a range of social contexts. Training in grammar and vocabulary that builds fluency, and in using the language appropriately for meaningful interactions with members of the Deaf community. For students with basic ASL conversational ability. Prerequisite: ASL 100. or by placement. Subject: Anatomy
Course Title: Gross Anatomy of the Limbs and Trunk
Course Description: Lectures and laboratory sessions on the human gross and functional anatomy of the limbs and trunk. The course includes the study of predissected specimens. For credit only in the Department of Physical Therapy.

Subject: Anatomy
Course Title: Human Anatomy for Physical Therapy Students
Course Description: Microscopic systems anatomy and regional anatomy of the nervous system. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: Registration in Rehabilitation Sciences (RSPT) is required.

Subject: Anatomy
Course Description: An introduction to the structure of the human nervous system. Given only in conjunction with PHYL 425. (Open to Medical and Dental students only.)

Subject: Anatomy
Course Description: An advanced lecture and laboratory course in the microscopic structure of the human body. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Anatomy
Course Description: Seminar discussions of current topics in vertebrate cell biology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Anatomy
Course Description: An examination of selected properties of the cell and underlying mechanisms based on the ultrastructure of the cell and on the physical chemistry of open systems. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Anatomy
Course Description: The gross and microscopic study of the nervous system in man. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Anatomy
Course Title: Fundamentals of Body Design: Basic Principles in Human Anatomy as Illustrated by the Organization of the Back and Upper Limb
Course Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Anatomy
Course Title: Functional Human Anatomy of Head and Neck Systems
Course Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Anatomy
Course Title: Functional Human Anatomy of the Respiratory, Cardiovascular and Gastrointestinal Systems of the Thorax and Abdomen
Course Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Anatomy
Course Title: Functional Human Anatomy of the Urogenital Systems: Pelvis and Perineum
Course Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Anatomy
Course Title: Functional Human Anatomy of the Musculoskeletal Systems: Back, Limbs and Joints
Course Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Anatomy
Course Title: Functional Human Neuroanatomy: Central Nervous System
Course Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Anatomy
Course Title: Functional Human Microscopic Anatomy: Basic Tissues, Organs and Systems
Course Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Anatomy
Course Description: Selected topics in muscle contraction at an advanced level Permission of Head required. Equivalency: PHYL530 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Anatomy
Course Title: Current Topics in the Morphological Sciences
Course Description: Lectures, demonstrations, discussions and student seminars on selected and current topics in cell biology and the anatomical sciences. Attendance is required of all M.Sc. and Ph.D. students in Anatomy & Cell Biology. [1-0-0] Prerequisite: Students must be registered in graduate-level studies in Anatomy & Cell Biology. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Anatomy
Course Title: Introduction to Functional Human Anatomy: Survey of Microscopic Anatomy, Neuroanatomy and Gross Anatomy
Course Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Greek and Latin Roots of English
Course Description: Greek and Latin roots of English vocabulary and grammar, with an introduction to language history and Greek and Roman culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 101 or AMNE 101.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Greek and Roman mythology and its interpretation. Emphasis on ancient texts read in English translation. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 105 or AMNE 151.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Introduction to Religions: Judaism, Christianity, Islam
Course Description: An overview of the foundational texts, histories, and contemporary expressions of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. Key concepts and approaches used in the study of religion. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 101, AMNE 160, or RGST 160. Equivalency: RGST 160

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Temples, Tombs, and Tyrants: The Archaeology of the Middle East, Greece, and Rome
Course Description: The rise of civilizations, cultural interconnections, and power dynamics in the ancient Middle East (including Egypt), Greece, and Rome (10,000 BCE - 300 CE). Archaeological methods and interpretation, and analysis of ancient artifacts in UBC collections. Credit will be granted for only one of CNRS 104 or AMNE 170.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Approaching the Ancient Mediterranean & Near East
Course Description: Orientation to the peoples, places, and traditions of the ancient Mediterranean and Near East, and to analyzing different forms of source material (historical, literary, archaeological) from different perspectives.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: A survey of the ancient Greek world from the Minoan and Mycenaean (about 2000-1000 BCE) to the Hellenistic Period (323-30 BCE). Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 231 or AMNE 215.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: A survey of the ancient Roman world from the foundation of the city to the death of Constantine. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 232 or AMNE 216.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Gladiators, Games, and Spectacle in the Greek and Roman World
Course Description: History, development, and social function of various forms of spectacle in ancient Greece and Rome, from the Olympic games to the Roman arena. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 260 or AMNE 225.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: The Pre-Socratics; Socrates; Sophists; Plato. Recommended as preparation for AMNE 236/PHIL 212 and PHIL 310. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 211, AMNE 235 or PHIL 211. Equivalency: PHIL211

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Aristotle; selections from Hellenistic and Late Antique Philosophy. Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310 and PHIL 311. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 212, AMNE 236 or PHIL 212. Equivalency: PHIL212

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: An introduction to the world of Near Eastern mythology, from the Gilgamesh Epic to the Book of Genesis and beyond. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 201 or AMNE 251.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: An introduction to the scriptures of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 203 or AMNE 260.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Eden to Exile: Introduction to the Hebrew Bible
Course Description: An overview of the Hebrew Bible (Old Testament), with emphasis on its ancient Near Eastern context; its competing religious perspectives; and its limits as a historical source. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 209 or AMNE 261.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Introduction to Judaism and its Texts
Course Description: What is Judaism? An overview of the key texts that have defined the Jewish religion, from the Hebrew Bible through works of contemporary thinkers. Recommended as a basis for upper-level courses in religious studies. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 206 or AMNE 262.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: The New Testament and Early Christianity
Course Description: The origins of Christianity as reflected in the New Testament and contemporaneous literature. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 316, AMNE 264, or AMNE 367.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: An introduction to the history of Christianity from its origins with Jesus through the coronation of Charlemagne as Roman Emperor in 800 CE.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: The Archaeology of Life and Death in the Roman Empire
Course Description: The lives of non-elite individuals and groups living under the Roman Empire, seen through material evidence and its interpretation. Identity, urbanism, economy, agriculture, diet, religion, Romanization, and burial. CNRS 104, AMNE 170 or ARCL 203 recommended as preparation. Credit will be granted for only one of CNRS 206 or AMNE 278.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Art, architecture, and material culture of the Byzantine Empire situated in the eastern Mediterranean (c. 300-1453); focus on social and cultural contexts of artistic production, including interactions with neighboring cultures. Credit will be granted for only one of CNRS 207, AMNE 279 or ARTH 210. Equivalency: ARTH210

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Modern receptions and engagements with literature, history, philosophy, religion, archaeology, and art of the ancient Mediterranean and Near East with a focus on public writing. Prerequisite: Second-year standing or higher. AMNE 200 is recommended.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: The Technical Terms of Medicine and Biological Science
Course Description: Acquaints the student with the Greek and Latin elements from which most specialized terms of modern medicine are constructed. Intended primarily for students planning to enter the medical, pharmaceutical, or biological sciences. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 301 or AMNE 301.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: The origins, achievements, and social impacts of applied technology in the Greek and Roman world from the Bronze Age to Late Antiquity (c. 1500 BCE - 400 CE), with special attention to archaeological evidence. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 306 or AMNE 306.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: A survey of the development and evolution of prehistoric humans and their material culture in Egypt from the Lower Paleolithic to the Chalcolithic. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 311 or AMNE 311.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: History and culture of Ancient Egyptian civilization from political, intellectual, social and environmental perspectives. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 303 or AMNE 312.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Early Empires of the Ancient Middle East
Course Description: A history from 3100-333 BC with emphasis on Mesopotamia. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 301 or AMNE 314.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: The sources (literary, epigraphical and other) for Athens' emergence as one of the two leading city-states in late archaic and classical Greece and the stages by which her empire grew. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 355 or AMNE 316. Prerequisite: One of CLST 231, AMNE 215.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Alexander the Great and his Empire
Course Description: The rise of Macedon under Philip II leading to its domination of Greece and the overthrow of the Persian Empire by his son, Alexander; the subsequent spread of Greek civilization in the East. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 356 or AMNE 317. Prerequisite: One of CLST 231, AMNE 215.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Rome from the foundation to the Augustan settlement. Constitutional development; the workings and failure of the Republican political system; acquisition and growth of Empire; the political, social, and economic consequences of imperialism. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 352 or AMNE 318. Prerequisite: One of CLST 232, AMNE 216.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Roman imperial history during the Julio-Claudian and Flavian periods (30 BC-96 AD). Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 353 or AMNE 319. Prerequisite: One of CLST 232, AMNE 216.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Topics in Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern History and Culture
Course Description: Selected topics in the history and culture of the ancient Mediterranean, Near East and/or Egypt.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Slavery in the Ancient Greek and Roman World
Course Description: The study and history of slavery in the Greek and Roman worlds as a political, legal, economic, social, and cultural phenomenon. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 320 or AMNE 323.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Women in the Bronze Age, Classical Greek and Hellenistic Cultures
Course Description: The images projected in mythology, literature, and art are compared with realities of women's lives insofar as they can be reconstructed from historical, legal, and archaeological records. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 311 or AMNE 324.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Women in the Roman World of Republican and Imperial Times
Course Description: Women in the Roman world in the culture of the Republic and the Empire. Literary, artistic, and mythological sources are compared and contrasted to historical, legal, and archaeological records. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 312 or AMNE 325.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Ancient Greek methods and tactics of war plus underlying social, religious and philosophical concepts relating to warfare, through sources in translation. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 329 or AMNE 326.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Rome's military from the early Republic to the Imperial period. Topics range from those of a military nature such as equipment and strategy to social topics such as policing and marriage of soldiers. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 319 or AMNE 327.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: History, sources, theoretical issues and current state of research about early Jewish legal traditions, focusing on close readings of classic primary texts in English translations. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 335 or AMNE 331.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: The study of Greek legal theory, practice, and institutions from their origin in self-help, through the early lawgivers and their codes, to the developed system of Athens in the fifth and fourth centuries. A variety of test cases from the works of the Greek orators will be explored. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 307 or AMNE 332.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: The development of Roman private law during the classical period with special attention to family law, contract and delict. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 308 or AMNE 333.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Topics in Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Literature and Ideas
Course Description: Selected topics in the literature, ideas, and arts of the ancient Mediterranean, Near East and/or Egypt.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Sex, Lies, and Violence in the Hebrew Bible
Course Description: An exploration of the Bible's dark side, with emphasis on texts that center on sex, deceit, and murder. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 307 or AMNE 341.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Key issues involved in translating the Bible, with attention to gender, sexuality, race, ethnicity, religion, and colonialism.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, in translation. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 313 or AMNE 345. Prerequisite: Second-year standing or above.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: The development of the epic genre in Latin, with detailed study of Vergil's Aeneid, Ovid's Metamorphoses, and Lucan's Civil War, in translation. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 314 or AMNE 346. Prerequisite: Second-year standing or above.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: The plays of the Greek and Roman comic dramatists: Aristophanes, Menander, Plautus and Terence, in translation. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 318 or AMNE 347. Prerequisite: Second-year standing and above.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: The plays of the Greek and Roman tragic dramatists, in translation. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 317 or AMNE 348. Recommended pre-requisite: One of CLST 105, AMNE 151. Restricted to students with second year standing or higher.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: A survey of the religious beliefs, cults, and religious institutions in Pharaonic Egypt. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 312 or AMNE 351.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: A survey of both traditional and exoteric religious practices from the Archaic to the Hellenistic period. Some knowledge of ancient Greece is recommended. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 333 or AMNE 355.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Roman religions between the ninth century BCE and the fourth century CE, including mystery religions, magic, emperor worship, and early Christianity, with particular attention devoted to the primary sources. Some knowledge of ancient Rome is recommended. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 334 or AMNE 356.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Topics in Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Religion
Course Description: Selected topics on the religions of the ancient Mediterranean, Near East and/or Egypt.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Surveys the history of Jews and Judaism in the Second Temple era, from the destruction of the First Jerusalem Temple (586 B.C.E.) to the beginnings of the rabbinic movement (200 C.E.). Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 330 or AMNE 361.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Talmud, Midrash and the Rabbinic Imagination
Course Description: The Talmud, Midrash, and other late-antique (3rd - 7th centuries) rabbinic writings, focusing on biblical interpretation and narratives. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 308 or AMNE 363.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Magic, Prophecy, and Divination in the Biblical World
Course Description: Textual, contextual, and comparative exploration of the reciprocal relations between gods and people in the Hebrew Bible, Near Eastern ritual texts, and ancient experience.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: The origins of Christianity as reflected in early Christian literature of the first and early second centuries (including the New Testament). Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 317 or AMNE 366.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Paul and the Making of Christianity
Course Description: Study of the controversial figure of Paul of Tarsus: his writings, impact, and reception, with attention to the contexts of ancient Judaism and the Roman Empire. AMNE 264 or previous experience reading the New Testament is recommended. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 415, AMNE 368, or AMNE 464.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: The figure of Jesus, his teachings, and his reception through literary and contextual analysis of the canonical and apocryphal gospels. Recommended: AMNE 264 or previous experience reading the New Testament. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 414, AMNE 369, or AMNE 463.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Topics in Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Archaelogy
Course Description: Selected topics on the art, archaeology and/or architecture of the ancient Mediterranean, Near East and/or Egypt.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Ancient Egypt: The Archaeology of the Land of the Pharaohs
Course Description: The material remains of the ancient Egyptians from monumental tombs and temples to the artifacts of daily life; the development of Egyptian civilization from the rise of the first rulers to its incorporation into the Roman Empire. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 304, AMNE 371 or ARTH 325. Equivalency: ARTH325

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: The Archaeology of Ancient Iraq and Syria: Babylon and Beyond
Course Description: An overview of the archaeology of the ancient Near East, with special emphasis on the civilizations of Mesopotamia, from the appearance of the first cities (c. 3400 BCE) to the end of the Persian period (c. 330 BCE). AMNE 170 recommended as preparation. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 319, AMNE 372 or ARTH 319. Equivalency: ARTH319

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: The impact of archaeological research on understanding the history and religion of ancient Israel. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 306 or AMNE 373.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: The visual culture of the ancient Greek world in the second and first millennia BCE, especially from c. 1000 to 30 BCE. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 331, AMNE 376 or ARTH 331. Equivalency: ARTH 331

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: The visual culture of the ancient Roman world from the 8th century BCE to the 4th century CE. Credit will be granted for only one of CLST 332, AMNE 377 or ARTH 332. Equivalency: ARTH 332

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Art and the Religious Transformation of the Late Roman Empire
Course Description: Visual culture and religious diversity of the Late Roman Empire (2nd-7th c.); social, political, and religious contexts of art, including diverse viewing practices and cultural frameworks. Credit will be granted for only one of CNRS 333, AMNE 379 or ARTH 310. Equivalency: ARTH 310

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Origins, nature, and transmission of myth in the Western tradition, with particular attention devoted to the interpretation of myth from ancient times up to the present. Some background in myth is recommended. Credit will be granted for only one of CNRS 370 or AMNE 381.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: The adaptation and appropriation of ancient Egypt in ancient and modern art, architecture, film, and music; the development of Egyptology since the 19th century. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 318 or AMNE 382.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Modern Jewish Ethics in Historical Perspective
Course Description: Readings from key texts in English translation, tracing how Jewish approaches to ethical issues evolved from biblical times to the present. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 313 or AMNE 383.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Language of Ancient Egypt and the main literary texts composed during the Middle Kingdom. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 313 or AMNE 391.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: The basic grammar and introduction to the cuneiform writing system of the Akkadian language of the Ancient Near East. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 315 or AMNE 392.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: An introduction to Coptic, the language of Christian Egypt from 100 AD. Credit will be granted for only one of NEST 317 or AMNE 393.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Basics of Imperial Aramaic grammar and vocabulary, with readings from biblical and other ancient sources from the eastern Mediterranean and Southwest and Central Asia.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Practicum in Ancient Mediterranean or Near Eastern Archaeology
Course Description: Training in excavation techniques and interpretation through participation in the excavation of a Greek, Roman, or Near Eastern site in Europe or the Middle East. The minimum length of the course is three weeks; it may be repeated once. A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 395 and CNRS 335. Students should consult the AMNE Undergraduate Advisor before registering.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Literature of Ancient Egypt or the Ancient Near East
Course Description: Topics in the main genres and texts of Egyptian and/or Ancient Near Eastern Literature and their modern interpretation. A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 441, NEST 401, NEST 505, and AMNE 541. Students should consult the AMNE Undergraduate Advisor before registering.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Selected topics in biblical and related texts. A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 461 or RELG 475. Students should consult the AMNE Undergraduate Advisor before registering. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Selected topics in Judaism and Hellenism, the rise of the synagogue, Jewish sects, the development of classical rabbinic literature (e.g., Mishnah, Talmud, Midrash). A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 462 or RELG 407. Students should consult the AMNE Undergraduate Advisor before registering.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: The Gospels and the Historical Jesus
Course Description: The canonical and apocryphal gospels and the life and teachings of the historical Jesus. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 414 or AMNE 463.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: The life and literature of Paul in the Roman imperial world: letter writing, patronage and power; Roman imperial iconography; Paul and community formation. Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 415 or AMNE 464.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Selected topics on the origins, development, and material manifestations of urbanism in the ancient Mediterranean, Near East and/or Egypt. A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 471, NEST 402, AMNE 571 and NEST 506. Students should consult the AMNE Undergraduate Advisor before registering.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: An overview of the archaeology of ancient Cyprus from the island's initial colonization in the 10th millennium BCE through the period of its rule as part of the Roman Empire (4th century CE). Credit will be granted for only one of CNRS 410 or AMNE 472.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Credit will be granted for only one of CNRS 449 or AMNE 499. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Pro-Seminar in Ancient Mediterranean Studies: Selected Topics
Course Description: A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 500 or CNRS 500. Students should consult the AMNE Graduate Advisor before registering. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 501 or NEST 503. Students should consult the AMNE Graduate Advisor before registering. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Topics in Greek History and Culture
Course Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Topics in Roman History and Culture
Course Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Literature of Ancient Egypt or the Ancient Near East
Course Description: Topics in the main genres and texts of Egyptian and/or Ancient Near Eastern Literature and their modern interpretation. A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 541, NEST 505, AMNE 441 or NEST 401. Students should consult the AMNE Graduate Advisor before registering. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 561 or RELG 500. Students should consult the AMNE Graduate Advisor before registering. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Studies in the texts (in translation), history, and religious thought of Judaism after the close of the Biblical Period. A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 562 or RELG 502. Students should consult the AMNE Graduate Advisor before registering. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Selected topics pertaining to the literature, history, and material culture of Christians from the first century CE through late antiquity. A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 563 or RELG 503. Students should consult the AMNE Graduate Advisor before registering. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Selected topics on the origins, development, and material manifestations of urbanism in the ancient Mediterranean, Near East and/or Egypt. A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 571, NEST 506, AMNE 471 or NEST 402. Students should consult the AMNE Graduate Advisor before registering. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 572 or NEST 500. Students should consult the AMNE Graduate Advisor before registering. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 575 or CLST 518. Students should consult with the AMNE Graduate Advisor before registering. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Study of a particular area, e.g., Ionia, Sicily, Southern Italy. A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 576 or CLST 511. Students should consult with the AMNE Graduate Advisor before registering. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 577 or CLST 519. Students should consult with the AMNE Graduate Advisor before registering. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Study of a particular area, e.g., Gaul, Britain, Asia Minor. A maximum of 6 credits will be granted for AMNE 578 or CLST 512. Students should consult with the AMNE Graduate Advisor before registering. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Theory and Method in the Study of Religion
Course Description: Credit will be granted for only one of RELG 531 or AMNE 581. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Ancient Mediterranean or Near Eastern Language Studies
Course Description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Title: Practicum in Ancient Mediterranean or Near Eastern Archaeology
Course Description: Training in excavation techniques and interpretation through participation in the excavation of a Greek, Roman, or Near Eastern site in Europe or the Middle East. The minimum length of the course is three weeks. Credit will be granted for only one of CNRS 535 or AMNE 595. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Ancient Mediterranean and Near Eastern Studies
Course Description: Credit will be granted for only one of CNRS 549 or AMNE 599. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Title: Introduction to Archaeology: Past perspectives and Future Promise
Course Description: A critical introductory overview to the discipline of archaeology, its functions and entanglements, and potential contributions and transformations for the future.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: The origin and evolution of the human lineage and the emergence of human biological and cultural traits with emphasis on the fossil record before the Pleistocene. Credit will be granted for only one of ARCL 140 or ANTH 225.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: Introduces the methods and principles applied in anthropological archaeology and cultural-historical research.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: An examination of some momentous discoveries in archaeology that have shaped our knowledge of the ancient world and the history of humanity.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: The application of methods from biological anthropology and archaeology to the identification, recovery, and analysis of skeletal remains from crime scenes, mass disasters, and unexplained deaths.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: Introductory survey of North American archaeology comparing the ancient cultures from all major regions of Canada and the US.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: The archaeology of ancient Mexico, Central and South America, highlighting recent discoveries about the emergence and growth of civilizations such as the Aztecs, Maya, Zapotec, Inca, Chimor and their ancestors.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Title: Taming the Wild: Animals, Alcohol and Agriculture
Course Description: How, when and why humans became dependent on cultivated foods and domestic animals and the methods used to document plant and animal domestication.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: Current theoretical developments explored through the practice of archaeology. Examples drawn from a range of times and places focusing on emerging technologies, food production, colonial encounters and culture contact, materiality and symbolic systems, social inequality and complexity, and human-environmental interactions.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: Intensive training in excavation techniques and interpretation, including mapping procedures, recording, preliminary analysis, and reporting. Students will participate in an excavation for the Summer Session and will use this excavation as a basis for lectures, discussions and reports. Additional Field Trip Fees are charged for this course.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Title: The Archaeology of Collapse and Sustainability
Course Description: An evaluation of the issues of sustainability and collapse of ecological and social systems through the archaeological study of the past.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: Early hunter-gatherer-forager societies, spanning the period from the emergence of the first tool-using hominins to the origins of agriculture.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Title: The Emergence of Complex Societies in Eurasia and Africa
Course Description: Archaeological evidence and theories for the origins and spread of settled village life, food production systems, and complex social and political organization: Early Neolithic period through to the appearance of the old world civilizations.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Title: Archaeological Foundations of East and Southeast Asia
Course Description: Survey of the archaeology of East and Southeast Asia, with an emphasis on the beginnings of the economic, social, political, and artistic traditions and systems of the great civilizations, and the conditions in which they arose. Theories of cultural development emphasizing Neolithic and state-level societies will be discussed.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: The archaeology of Mexico and Central America with an emphasis on the emergence of economic, social, political, and religious organization. Seminar format discussing recent research and current discoveries.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: The archaeology of South America with an emphasis on the emergence of economic, social, political, and religious organization, and a primary focus on the Andean region. Seminar format with lectures discussing recent research and current discoveries.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: Origin and development of the hominins; the hominin fossil record, and theories relating to hominin evolution. Prerequisite: ARCL 140.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: A comprehensive survey of primates, with emphasis on evolution, ecology, social organization, social behaviour, and field studies. Prerequisite: ARCL 140.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: Molecular techniques in archaeology and their application to anthropological and archaeological research.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: Current methods in mapping spatial information in archaeology and related subfields of anthropology.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: A survey of methods and techniques in the interpretation of archaeological data; practical experience in processing and analyzing archaeological materials by means of a research project. Students will prepare manuscripts, drawings and photographs for publication and will learn the basics of lithic and faunal analyses.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: Analysis of the archaeology of a specific areal, methodological, and theoretical topic, including a summary of the literature and examination of specific sites and analytical issues. The area covered will vary according to the instructor's expertise.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Title: Prehistory of a Special Area in the New World
Course Description: Analysis of the prehistory of a selected New World area, including a summary of the literature and discussion of relevant problems. The course will provide background for students in North, Central, and South American area studies. Typical offerings include the prehistory of Mesoamerica, the Southwest, North America and the Mayan areas.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: A survey of methods, theory, and case-studies in mortuary archaeology. Prerequisite: ARCL 203.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Title: First Nations Archaeology of British Columbia
Course Description: An advanced study of the prehistoric archaeology of coastal and interior Native Peoples. A critical analysis of the archaeological evidence and interpretations of prehistoric cultural developments from the earliest migrations up to historical contact.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Title: Practising Archaeology and the Management of Cultural Resources
Course Description: Survey of the use of archaeology in the public context and interest, particularly the identification, evaluation, conservation, and management of archaeological resources. Laws and policies, principles, methods, and ethical concerns guiding current practices, public involvement, relationships with indigenous communities, and contemporary issues in cultural resources management.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: The archaeological evidence for the change of human diets over time and the methods used to reconstruct past diets.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Description: Analytical and practical skills in locating archaeological sites and data leading to spatial patterns and historical interpretation.

Subject: Anthropological Archaeology
Course Title: Culture Through the Animal Body: Fundamentals of Zooarchaeology
Course Description: Methods to study animal bones and shell remains to understand the ways that people acquired food, negotiated their social status, and contributed to ceremonial practices. Prerequisite: ARCL 103.
